newsitem.title: CHINA: China lauds economic succcess, vows more reform.
newsitem.headline: China lauds economic succcess, vows more reform.

text.p: China's rulers on Sunday concluded a top-level meeting on the economy in Beijing by lauding the country's success in reining in inflation and vowing to push ahead with reforms of the state sector in 1997.
"China's macro-economic control with the curbing of inflation as the primary task has met the pre-set target," the official Xinhua news agency said.

President Jiang Zemin, Premier Li Peng and the country's top economic planner Zhu Rongji attended the four-day conference to review this year's economic performance and chart the course of development for 1997, Xinhua said.

China would continue with a moderately tight monetary policy to try to keep a cap on inflation, which has been Beijing's top priority in setting economic policy over the past several years, the agency said.
Official forecasts say inflation in 1996 will be about 6.5 percent in 1996, down from last year's 14.8 percent and 1994's communist-era high of 21.7 percent.
"Work will continue to readjust and control the range of price rises and lower the growth rate of prices," Xinhua said.
"A good macro-economic environment and standardised economic order should be maintained, adhering to a moderately tight financial and monetary control."
Officials said tackling the sensitive issue of reform of loss-making state firms would be a priority for next year's economic development.
"Reform and development of state-owned enterprises must be accelerated, and economic efficiency of enterprises must be vigorously improved," Xinhua said.
About 70 percent of China's hundreds of thousands of state firms are running in the red, 40 percent with chronic deficits, official statistics show.
Beijing has been reluctant to push ahead with reform of the wheezing state sector, fearing that mass unemployment and loss of cradle-to-grave welfare could spark social unrest.
The meeting also pledged to forge ahead with agricultural reforms and continue an opening up policy launched by paramount leader Deng Xiaoping in 1979, Xinhua said.
"Opening to the outside world represents a basic policy of the country and must be pursued unswervingly over a long period," it added.
